title: 107_s638
content: The Act is titled the "Art and Collectibles Capital Gains Tax Treatment Parity Act" and it addresses the capital gains treatment for art and collectibles. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to define '28-percent rate gain' as the excess of section 1202 gain over the sum of net short-term capital loss and long-term capital loss carried to the taxable year. Conforming amendments are made to align with the changes. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to define '28-percent rate gain' as the excess of section 1202 gain over the sum of net short-term capital loss and long-term capital loss carried to the taxable year. Conforming amendments are made to align with the changes. The amendments made by this section shall apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2000. SEC. 3. Charitable contributions of certain items created by the taxpayer. SEC. 3 amends subsection (e) of section 170 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to include a special rule for certain contributions of literary, musical, or artistic compositions. For qualified artistic charitable contributions, the fair market value of the property contributed is used without any reduction in the amount of the contribution. The term 'qualified artistic charitable contribution' refers to a donation of literary, musical, artistic, or scholarly compositions created by the taxpayer at least 18 months prior to the contribution. The taxpayer must also obtain a qualified appraisal of the fair market value of the property. The taxpayer must adhere to regulations and attach an appraisal to their income tax return for a charitable contribution. The donee organization must use the property for its exempt purpose under section 501, and the taxpayer must receive confirmation from the donee. The taxpayer must provide a written statement from the donee confirming the use of the donated property and the appraisal must show evidence of similar property being owned or displayed by qualifying organizations. The taxpayer's deduction increase for donated property is limited to their artistic adjusted gross income for the taxable year, with no carryover allowed. The term 'artistic adjusted gross income' is defined within the context. The term 'artistic adjusted gross income' refers to the portion of the taxpayer's adjusted gross income attributable to income from personal efforts related to the donated property, including income from teaching or similar activities. This definition does not apply to certain contributions like letters or memoranda. The amendment specifies that a copyright on a qualified artistic charitable contribution is treated separately from the tangible literary, musical, artistic, or scholarly composition for tax purposes. This amendment applies to contributions made after the enactment of the Act. Contributions made after the enactment of this Act in taxable years ending after such date.
